Thanks for posting this Pete! The Farm Bill is one of the biggest and most important bills that Congress passes and it receives far too little attention on the part of the general public. I am hopeful, but far from confident, that the Biden Administration might begin to make some significant changes to this and begin to dismantle corn as a platform. But the entrenched interests are powerful and have long and deep relationships with the politicians whose campaigns they contribute to, It‚Äôll be an uphill battle for sure‚Ä¶

item.description:
I wanted to post one of my favorite rants, from December 2018. It‚Äôs related to US capitalism, finance, real estate, and ‚Äúfarming‚Äù.

In the following, ‚Äúcorn,‚Äù ‚Äúmaize,‚Äù and ‚Äúsoybeans‚Äù refer to the industrial varieties which humans don‚Äôt eat, but which make up most of what the US grows. Think industrial feedstocks; not popcorn, corn on the cob, or edamame.

SwiftOnSecurity started:

twitter.com

SwiftOnSecurity (SwiftOnSecurity)

You live in a society whose every production industry is based around a government-subsidized chemical feedstock. Corn is not a _food_. Corn is a _platform_.

SwiftOnSecurity @SwiftOnSecurity

You‚Äôve got government market subsidy, political weight of low-population states, energy insecurity, environmental issues, agribusiness consolidation, hyper-productivity despite decreasing labor, food basket dynamics in world wars, 20th century chemical revolution, obesity, etc
3:59 PM - 17 Dec 2018 7.2K 2.2K

(scroll up and down that thread for enough examples to make you sick)

And Dr. Taber picked up from there:

twitter.com

Dr Sarah Taber (SarahTaber_bww)

Enter maize & soybeans. Here's what they bring to table: 1) Short-lived enough to make use of Midwest growing season 2) Need lots of water- that cuts out competition from the US West 3) Humans can't eat them, but that's ok, they're just infinitely fungible starch & protein. https://t.co/Gk4bemgYzJ

Dr Sarah Taber @SarahTaber_bww

GOD YES SOMEONE FINALLY EXPLAINED IT https://twitter.com/SwiftOnSecurity/status/1074856487514726400 ‚Ä¶
8:22 PM - 17 Dec 2018 809 120

Corn is a platform with both limitless purposes, and one purpose:

to turn rural land into a dependable & infinitely fungible financial asset.

If you want to understand US agriculture, you gotta understand one thing.

It‚Äôs not even about making food.

It‚Äôs a real estate hustle.

Can I be honest for a second, as an ag person who‚Äôs done most of their work in CA & the South?

Land in the Midwest ‚Ä¶ isn‚Äôt really good for much. Sure, the soil‚Äôs real nice, but the growing season is too short for most globally-traded cash crops.

Coffee.

Sugar.

Chocolate.

Cotton.

Tobacco.

Rice.

Palm oil.

The Midwest is exactly the kind of giant wet low-population area you‚Äôd want for cash crops. Except most of the big-money ones are tropical, & Midwest has a 3-6 month growing season. You‚Äôre stuck with annual crops.

‚ÄúWell what‚Äôs wrong w wheat, flax, oats, rye, hemp, & other short-season cash crops?‚Äù

  1. Hemp ain‚Äôt been legal

  2. We can‚Äôt use an entire Midwest‚Äôs worth of oats & rye

  3. Wheat & flax grow nearly everywhere, including huge areas of arid US west. Too much competition to rely on.

Enter maize & soybeans. Here‚Äôs what they bring to table:

  1. Short-lived enough to make use of Midwest growing season

  2. Need lots of water- that cuts out competition from the US West

  3. Humans can‚Äôt eat them, but that‚Äôs ok, they‚Äôre just infinitely fungible starch & protein.

If you‚Äôre just growing raw sources of starch & protein, you can just handle market gluts by inventing a new use. That‚Äôs harder to do with crops that make something less malleable like fiber, or (in case of wheat, oats, rye, & most grains) a mid-yield mix of starch & protein.

And boy do we get our market gluts on. Because for 3-6 months every year, the Midwest turns into a giant hot wet basin of plant growing power.

But: without a platform like corn & soybeans, hot wet plains are just hot wet plains. They‚Äôre not a financial powerhouse. You couldn‚Äôt, say, include farmland as a securitized asset in investment funds.

https://www.cnbc.com/2016/01/21/getting-your-plot-of-american-farmland-.html

The Food Discourse‚Ñ¢ really fixates on how corn is used after it‚Äôs grown. ‚ÄúOh my God! It‚Äôs in everything!‚Äù

I‚Äôm more interested in what that means for those who possess the land to grow it & what that means for our society. And @SwiftOnSecurity hit the nail on the head.

Part of the Food Discourse ‚Ñ¢‚Äôs fascination with food manufacturing is that it‚Äôs fairly recent. It feels new & foreign. And, you can see the size of the facilities and visualize the money that it takes to build and run them.

It‚Äôs a fairly new way to accumulate wealth. It‚Äôs visible. And it fits with our ‚Äúwealth is capital is manufacturing & Wall Street‚Äù mentality. So we fixate on it.

Meanwhile, most folks have no idea what the value of farmland is. Or that subsidies don‚Äôt go to the people growing the corn- they go to the people who own the land it grows on.

Most folks have no idea that the big hustle in food isn‚Äôt food. It‚Äôs real estate.

That doesn‚Äôt fit with our image of how wealth works in a capitalist society.

Capitalism is supposed to mean new, modern, and scary! Farmland is ancient and wholesome! Farming is our one connection to more wholesome times!

Bullshit.

Farm landlords were grinding people to death for thousands of years before capitalism was ever invented.

Real estate‚Äôs always been the ideal asset. Can be used for food, minerals, or development- and you can collect rents pretty much infinitely w zero work.

But thanks to our focus on ‚Äúbad stuff in our economy = modern = capitalism = industry‚Äù & ‚Äúagriculture = old = good,‚Äù we rarely see farmland as being an asset that can be traded globally.

AND THAT‚ÄôS EXACTLY HOW THE GOD DAMN LANDLORDS WANT IT

We‚Äôre busy fretting about agribusiness and food processing, meanwhile real live land barons are out here collecting rent & subsidy checks on millions of acres and using it as low-risk ballast for their portfolios.

To be clear: Wall Street is part of this.

So are good ol‚Äô boys.

Most rural counties are run by 2-3 families that quietly own a huge slice of the land. You want to know why rural areas are so fucked up? It ain‚Äôt the coastal elites. It‚Äôs the landlords right there in the county.

Rural landlords might collect their rent checks directly from their serfs, I mean neighbors in the county instead of a hedge fund office in Manhattan. But they‚Äôve got the same job. Own land, futz around all day, profit.

Ever notice how most proposals to solve farm-related problems- not enough food, too much food, soil conservation, wildlife conservation, water shortages-

all seem to boil down to ‚Äúthrow money at land owners‚Äù?

Isn‚Äôt that weird?

The philosophy behind conservation payments is sometimes people own farmland that‚Äôs too fragile to farm.

But not farming loses money! Therefore, we must pay them not to farm it!

Is anybody asking why own ‚Äúfarmland‚Äù that can‚Äôt be farmed in the first place?

This is a problem that could be solved a lot of different ways. Trusts, land buybacks, tax writeoffs for donating to conservation, etc. These are all used to some extent.

But the big federal programs are all built around sending landowners a reliable subsidy check every year.

So ‚Ä¶ yeah. Sometimes rural land ownership is just an instrument for rich people to extort bribes from taxpayers. ‚ÄúPay me or I‚Äôll ruin your water.‚Äù

And sometimes you just monetize it on the corn platform.

Either way, it‚Äôs a huge asset class. In many ways it‚Äôs more influential & politically powerful than the ‚Äúindustrial food‚Äù sector we‚Äôve been taught to fear. But it‚Äôs invisible, distant, and quiet, monetizing the earth in ways few of us understand.
